SENT.plain: Dementia has been found to display a more heterogeneous clinical picture than previously recognized

We investigated brain changes on computed tomography (CT) in a clinical dementia population consisting of 67 cases with Alzheimer's disease (AD), 13 with mixed dementia (AD and vascular dementia, VaD), 71 with VaD, and 12 cases that were not demented
Temporal cortical atrophy and atrophy around the temporal horns were more common in patients with mixed dementia compared to patients with VaD and the non-demented, respectively
Frontal white matter changes were present in 64% of AD, in 85% of mixed dementia and in 79% of VaD cases, but there were no differences between the dementia groups
Lacunes were present in almost 40% of AD cases and in 80 and 85% of VaD and mixed dementia cases, respectively
Only 14% of the VaD cases had large infarcts on the CT
We conclude that large infarcts were rare, even in VaD cases
The increased incidence of white matter changes and lacunes in AD patients strongly indicates an underestimation of the mixed dementia diagnosis
More distinct criteria for this diagnostic category are warranted
